query: AI scientific discovery automated hypothesis generation knowledge graph LLM reasoning literature review research question generation bibliometric analysis semantic similarity scientific knowledge base

concepts.label: Knowledge Graph
concepts.description: A structured, semantic representation of entities and their relationships, used to organize product data in a machine-interpretable format.

concepts.label: Large Language Model
concepts.description: A deep learning model trained on vast text corpora to understand and generate human language, capable of performing information extraction and reasoning tasks.

concepts.label: AI Agent
concepts.description: An autonomous software entity capable of perceiving its environment, reasoning, and taking actions to achieve defined goals using LLMs or symbolic logic.

concepts.label: Ontology
concepts.description: A formal, explicit specification of concepts, properties, and relationships within a domain, defining the schema for structured knowledge representation.

concepts.label: Product Description
concepts.description: Unstructured textual data provided by e-commerce sellers to characterize product features, specifications, and properties.

concepts.label: Ontology Creation
concepts.description: The automated process of identifying and extracting key concepts, entities, and their relationships from unstructured text to define a domain schema.

concepts.label: Ontology Refinement
concepts.description: The iterative improvement of ontology structure by resolving inconsistencies, eliminating redundancy, and ensuring semantic coherence.

concepts.label: Knowledge Graph Population
concepts.description: The process of extracting entity instances and relationships from source data and inserting them into a knowledge graph structure.

concepts.label: Information Retrieval
concepts.description: The task of finding relevant information or documents from large repositories in response to user queries.

concepts.label: Recommendation System
concepts.description: An algorithmic system that predicts user preferences and suggests relevant items based on historical data and similarity metrics.

concepts.label: Semantic Coherence
concepts.description: The property of a knowledge representation ensuring that meanings of entities and relationships are consistent, non-contradictory, and logically aligned.

concepts.label: Property Coverage
concepts.description: A metric quantifying the proportion of relevant product attributes and relationships successfully extracted and represented in a knowledge graph.

concepts.label: E-Commerce Platform
concepts.description: An online marketplace or system enabling the buying and selling of products, generating large volumes of structured and unstructured data.

concepts.label: Agent-Driven Framework
concepts.description: A system architecture employing multiple specialized AI agents that coordinate to automate complex multi-stage knowledge extraction and organization tasks.

concepts.label: particle physics
concepts.description: Fundamental branch of physics studying elementary particles, their interactions, and the forces governing the subatomic world.

concepts.label: science outreach
concepts.description: Systematic efforts to communicate and popularise scientific knowledge to general audiences, students, and educators outside academic institutions.

concepts.label: science education
concepts.description: Structured teaching and learning of scientific concepts and methods, typically in school and formal educational settings.

concepts.label: IPPOG
concepts.description: International Particle Physics Outreach Group, a collaborative organization dedicated to presenting and popularising particle physics across diverse audiences since 1997.

concepts.label: Resource Database
concepts.description: Online platform providing a curated collection of high-quality educational and outreach materials in particle physics and related sciences.

concepts.label: fundamental research
concepts.description: Scientific investigation aimed at understanding basic principles and mechanisms of nature rather than direct practical applications.

concepts.label: educational materials
concepts.description: Pedagogical resources and tools designed to facilitate learning and understanding of scientific concepts.

concepts.label: scientific community
concepts.description: Collective body of researchers, educators, and institutions engaged in systematic scientific inquiry and knowledge creation.

concepts.label: Large language models
concepts.description: Neural network models trained on vast text corpora capable of extracting key concepts and semantic relationships beyond keyword-based methods.

concepts.label: Interdisciplinary scientific discovery
concepts.description: Research advancement driven by the integration of concepts, methods, and technologies from multiple distinct scientific domains.

concepts.label: Numerical simulations
concepts.description: Computational techniques used to model and solve complex physical systems in astronomical research through mathematical algorithms.

concepts.label: Machine learning
concepts.description: Algorithmic approaches for automated pattern recognition and predictive modeling applied to astronomical data analysis and discovery.

concepts.label: Astronomical research
concepts.description: The scientific study of celestial objects, structures, and phenomena using observational and computational methods.

concepts.label: Citation-reference relationships
concepts.description: Linkages between scientific publications indicating knowledge dependency and concept relevance over time.

concepts.label: Concept extraction
concepts.description: Automated identification and identification of key semantic units and ideas from scientific literature using language processing.

concepts.label: Technology integration phase
concepts.description: The initial stage of technology adoption in scientific research where new methods are incorporated into established practices.

concepts.label: Scientific exploration phase
concepts.description: The subsequent stage where newly integrated technologies are applied to generate novel scientific discoveries and insights.

concepts.label: AI-astronomy intersection
concepts.description: The convergence domain where artificial intelligence methods and astronomical research methodologies meet to create novel approaches.

concepts.label: Scientific breakthrough
concepts.description: Significant advancement or discovery that substantially advances understanding or enables new research directions in a scientific field.

concepts.label: Technological advancement
concepts.description: Development and refinement of new computational, observational, or analytical methods that enhance research capabilities.

concepts.label: Relational database
concepts.description: A database management system organizing data into tables with rows and columns, structured according to the relational model.

concepts.label: Semantic mapping
concepts.description: The process of establishing correspondences between data elements in one schema and concepts in a standardized vocabulary or ontology.

concepts.label: Semantic agent
concepts.description: An autonomous computational entity leveraging language models to interpret and map data semantics across systems.

concepts.label: Schema.org
concepts.description: A collaborative vocabulary project providing standardized schemas for structured data markup on the web.

concepts.label: Multi-agent system
concepts.description: A distributed computational system comprising multiple independent agents that interact and collaborate to solve complex problems.

concepts.label: Data integration
concepts.description: The process of combining data from multiple heterogeneous sources into a unified and consistent view.

concepts.label: Data interoperability
concepts.description: The ability of disparate information systems and data sources to exchange and utilize data seamlessly.

concepts.label: Semantic layer
concepts.description: An abstraction level above raw data that provides semantic meaning and relationships, enabling higher-level interpretation.

concepts.label: Table-to-term mapping
concepts.description: The assignment of database tables and columns to standardized vocabulary terms or ontology concepts.

concepts.label: cognitive flow
concepts.description: Optimal cognitive state characterized by deep focus, intrinsic motivation, and immersion when task difficulty aligns with individual skill level.

concepts.label: flow theory
concepts.description: Psychological framework describing conditions under which individuals experience optimal engagement and intrinsic motivation in activities.

concepts.label: AI-augmented reasoning
concepts.description: Decision-making and cognitive processes enhanced through artificial intelligence systems that provide support and augmentation.

concepts.label: cognitive intervention
concepts.description: Actions or system responses designed to influence, adjust, or support cognitive processes during reasoning and decision-making.

concepts.label: context-aware augmentation
concepts.description: AI framework that adapts cognitive support dynamically based on contextual factors including intervention type, timing, and scale.

concepts.label: multimodal behavioral cues
concepts.description: Multi-source signals capturing user state and engagement, including gaze behavior, typing hesitation, and interaction speed.

concepts.label: task difficulty
concepts.description: Objective measure of challenge level associated with a cognitive task.

concepts.label: skill level
concepts.description: Individual's current capability or proficiency in executing a particular task or domain.

concepts.label: gaze behavior
concepts.description: Eye movement patterns and visual attention metrics used as a behavioral signal of cognitive engagement.

concepts.label: intrinsic motivation
concepts.description: Internal drive to engage in an activity for inherent satisfaction rather than external reward.

concepts.label: intervention timing
concepts.description: Temporal placement and scheduling of cognitive support actions relative to user need and task progression.

concepts.label: intervention scale
concepts.description: Magnitude, intrusiveness, or scope of cognitive support provided by AI systems.

concepts.label: cognitive immersion
concepts.description: State of deep engagement and absorption in a cognitive task with minimal distraction from external factors.

concepts.label: decision-making
concepts.description: Cognitive process of selecting among alternatives based on reasoning and evaluation.

concepts.label: Clinical knowledge
concepts.description: Insights from medical research on the causes, prognosis, diagnosis, and treatment of diseases.

concepts.label: Medical LLMs
concepts.description: Large language models specifically trained or adapted for medical applications such as diagnostic assistance and treatment recommendations.

concepts.label: Knowledge graphs
concepts.description: Structured representations of domain knowledge using nodes and edges to encode entities, relationships, and semantic information.

concepts.label: Retrieval-augmented generation
concepts.description: Technique that enhances LLM outputs by retrieving relevant external documents or data before generating responses.

concepts.label: Diagnostic assistance
concepts.description: Clinical application where AI systems support physicians in identifying diseases or conditions from symptoms and test results.

concepts.label: Treatment recommendations
concepts.description: Clinical application where AI systems suggest therapeutic interventions based on patient data and medical evidence.

concepts.label: Multimodal data integration
concepts.description: Method of combining multiple data modalities (text, images, structured data) to improve model understanding and performance.

concepts.label: Medical datasets
concepts.description: Curated collections of medical data including patient records, research publications, and domain-specific resources for training and evaluation.

concepts.label: Knowledge sources
concepts.description: Authoritative medical databases, literature, and documentation that serve as reliable foundations for embedding clinical knowledge.

concepts.label: Decision-making traceability
concepts.description: Capability of medical AI systems to provide interpretable and auditable explanations for their clinical recommendations.

concepts.label: Model evaluation
concepts.description: Assessment of LLM performance on medical tasks using appropriate metrics and benchmarks to measure accuracy and reliability.

concepts.label: literature review automation
concepts.description: Automated generation of literature summaries and reviews from academic documents using computational methods.

concepts.label: Natural Language Processing
concepts.description: Computational techniques for analyzing, understanding, and generating human language text.

concepts.label: frequency-based method
concepts.description: Text summarization technique using word/term frequency statistics to identify and extract salient sentences.

concepts.label: transformer model
concepts.description: Neural architecture based on self-attention mechanisms for sequence-to-sequence tasks including text summarization.

concepts.label: ROUGE score
concepts.description: Automatic evaluation metric measuring overlap between generated and reference text using n-gram matching and longest common subsequence.

concepts.label: SciTLDR dataset
concepts.description: Scientific document benchmark dataset containing research paper abstracts paired with reference summaries for evaluation.

concepts.label: PDF document processing
concepts.description: Extraction and parsing of text content from PDF files as primary input source for automated systems.

concepts.label: graphical user interface
concepts.description: Interactive visual system allowing end-users to access and utilize the literature review generation system.

concepts.label: Visual Question Answering
concepts.description: A multimodal task requiring models to answer natural language questions about images by integrating visual and textual understanding.

concepts.label: Knowledge reasoning
concepts.description: The process of leveraging external knowledge bases to infer answers beyond direct image and text correlation.

concepts.label: Annotator bias
concepts.description: Systematic distortions introduced by human annotators during crowdsourced dataset creation that lead to spurious correlations.

concepts.label: Shortcut learning
concepts.description: The phenomenon where models exploit superficial input-output correlations rather than learning robust semantic relationships.

concepts.label: Deep representation embedding
concepts.description: Neural network-based methods for learning distributed representations of multimodal data.

concepts.label: Visual Genome scene graph
concepts.description: A structured representation encoding objects, attributes, and relationships in images as a knowledge graph.

concepts.label: External knowledge base
concepts.description: A structured repository of factual triplets encoding relationships between entities independent of visual content.

concepts.label: Controlled program generation
concepts.description: A systematic procedure for constructing question-answer pairs using predefined rules applied to knowledge structures.

concepts.label: Knowledge triplet
concepts.description: A structured semantic unit encoding a relation between two entities in the form (subject, relation, object).

concepts.label: Multi-step reasoning
concepts.description: Inference requiring sequential application of multiple reasoning steps to derive an answer.

concepts.label: Image perception
concepts.description: The ability of a model to accurately extract and understand visual content from images.

concepts.label: Question understanding
concepts.description: The process of parsing and semantically interpreting natural language questions.

concepts.label: Answer distribution balance
concepts.description: A property ensuring that answers are represented with approximately equal frequency across a dataset to prevent bias.

concepts.label: Hierarchical deconstruction
concepts.description: Method of breaking down complex questions into simpler sub-problems organized by depth or prerequisite knowledge.

concepts.label: DepthQA dataset
concepts.description: Dataset containing questions deconstructed into three hierarchical depths: conceptual, procedural, and strategic knowledge.

concepts.label: Conceptual knowledge
concepts.description: Understanding of foundational concepts and definitions required as the first depth level of question deconstruction.

concepts.label: Procedural knowledge
concepts.description: Knowledge of methods and steps for solving problems, representing the second depth level of question deconstruction.

concepts.label: Strategic knowledge
concepts.description: High-level analytical understanding and synthesis skills required for complex problem-solving at the third depth level.

concepts.label: Backward discrepancy
concepts.description: Performance gap where LLMs answer complex questions but fail on simpler prerequisite sub-problems.

concepts.label: Model capacity
concepts.description: Size or capability level of an LLM, ranging from smaller to larger models.

concepts.label: Training data memorization
concepts.description: Phenomenon where models may have memorized specific examples from training data affecting their reasoning patterns.

concepts.label: Multi-turn interaction
concepts.description: Sequential dialogue-based guidance from simpler to complex questions to improve model reasoning performance.

concepts.label: Graph-based framework
concepts.description: Representation of questions and dependencies as nodes and edges in a directed graph structure.

concepts.label: Factual knowledge
concepts.description: Explicit, structured information about entities, relations, and facts that can be stored and accessed from external sources.

concepts.label: Black-box model
concepts.description: A model whose internal decision-making processes and reasoning are opaque and difficult to interpret.

concepts.label: KG-enhanced LLMs
concepts.description: Framework that incorporates knowledge graphs into LLMs during pre-training or inference phases to improve knowledge capture and interpretability.

concepts.label: LLM-augmented KGs
concepts.description: Framework that leverages LLMs to improve knowledge graph tasks including embedding, completion, construction, and question answering.

concepts.label: Synergized LLMs + KGs
concepts.description: Framework where LLMs and KGs play equal roles and work bidirectionally to enhance each other through mutually beneficial interaction.

concepts.label: KG embedding
concepts.description: Technique to represent entities and relations in a knowledge graph as continuous vector embeddings in a low-dimensional space.

concepts.label: KG completion
concepts.description: Task of predicting missing links or facts in a knowledge graph based on existing entities and relations.

concepts.label: KG construction
concepts.description: Process of automatically extracting and organizing entities and relations to build or expand knowledge graphs.

concepts.label: Graph-to-text generation
concepts.description: Task of generating natural language descriptions from structured knowledge graph representations.

concepts.label: Question answering
concepts.description: Task of automatically retrieving or generating answers to natural language questions using knowledge bases or language models.

concepts.label: Bidirectional reasoning
concepts.description: Reasoning process where both data-driven inferences from LLMs and knowledge-driven inferences from KGs mutually inform and enhance each other.

concepts.label: Relationship extraction
concepts.description: Computational technique for identifying and classifying semantic relationships between entities mentioned in text.

concepts.label: Scientific knowledge graphs
concepts.description: Knowledge graphs specifically focused on the scholarly domain, containing metadata about research publications, authors, venues, organizations, and research topics.

concepts.label: Text Mining
concepts.description: Computational process of extracting structured information and patterns from unstructured text documents.

concepts.label: Research publications
concepts.description: Scholarly papers and articles documenting scientific research, innovations, and findings in various domains.

concepts.label: Semantic Web
concepts.description: Web technologies and standards for representing and sharing structured knowledge on the World Wide Web using machine-readable formats.

concepts.label: Paper metadata
concepts.description: Structured descriptive information about research publications including authors, publication venues, organizations, research topics, and citations.

concepts.label: corpus distillation
concepts.description: Process of selecting and refining high-quality subsets of scientific text data to improve training efficiency and effectiveness for language models.

concepts.label: biomedical LLMs
concepts.description: Large language models specifically trained and optimized for biomedical and life sciences domains.

concepts.label: MeSH hierarchy
concepts.description: Medical Subject Headings controlled vocabulary and tree structure organizing biomedical concepts hierarchically for literature indexing.

concepts.label: biomedical ontologies
concepts.description: Formal, structured representations of biomedical knowledge and concepts with defined relationships and hierarchies.

concepts.label: question-answer pair generation
concepts.description: Automated creation of paired questions and answers from textual sources for training and evaluating language models.

concepts.label: biomedical question-answering
concepts.description: Task of automatically generating correct answers to domain-specific questions in biomedical and medical contexts.

concepts.label: scientific corpus
concepts.description: Large collection of scientific literature, publications, and annotated biomedical texts used as training data.

concepts.label: self-evaluation mechanism
concepts.description: Automated process where agents assess and validate the quality of generated data without external supervision.

concepts.label: LLM training data quality
concepts.description: Measure of relevance, accuracy, and domain-specificity of textual data used to train language models.

concepts.label: Llama3-70B
concepts.description: Open-source large language model with 70 billion parameters used as a baseline for biomedical task evaluation.

concepts.label: GPT-4 with MedPrompt
concepts.description: Advanced proprietary language model enhanced with medical prompt engineering techniques for biomedical reasoning.

concepts.label: Entity Embedding
concepts.description: A continuous vector representation of an entity learned to capture its semantic properties and relationships.

concepts.label: Relation Embedding
concepts.description: A continuous vector representation of a relation type that models the semantic meaning of connections between entities.

concepts.label: Attention Mechanism
concepts.description: A neural mechanism that learns to weight or focus on different parts of input data, allowing selective emphasis on relevant information.

concepts.label: Message Passing
concepts.description: A neural network framework where information is propagated through graph nodes via learned transformations along edges.

concepts.label: Local Neighbors
concepts.description: The immediately adjacent entities and relations directly connected to a target entity in a knowledge graph.

concepts.label: Long-term Dependencies
concepts.description: Relationships and contextual information between distant entities that span multiple steps in a graph structure.

concepts.label: Semantic Path
concepts.description: A sequence of relations connecting two entities through intermediate nodes, capturing semantic relationships between them.

concepts.label: Context Information
concepts.description: The surrounding relational and semantic structure that provides meaning and constraints to an entity or relation.

concepts.label: knowledge emergence
concepts.description: The process by which new scientific knowledge develops and becomes institutionally, semantically, and cognitively integrated into scientific discourse.

concepts.label: scientific communication
concepts.description: The institutional and semantic systems through which scientists exchange, codify, and disseminate findings and concepts.

concepts.label: fullerenes
concepts.description: Allotropic form of carbon discovered in 1985, consisting of closed polyhedral cage structures such as C60 buckminsterfullerene.

concepts.label: nanotubes
concepts.description: One-dimensional nanostructures composed of rolled graphite sheets, derived as a conceptual and material extension of fullerene research.

concepts.label: network analysis
concepts.description: A methodological approach to map and quantify relationships and structure within complex systems such as scientific communication networks.

concepts.label: scientific discovery
concepts.description: The identification and characterization of previously unknown phenomena, materials, or principles that trigger subsequent research directions.

concepts.label: semantic codification
concepts.description: The process of translating and encoding concepts, discoveries, and meanings into linguistic and terminological structures within scientific literature.

concepts.label: institutional structure
concepts.description: The organizational framework of science, including journals, research groups, and publication venues through which knowledge circulates.

concepts.label: cognitive integration
concepts.description: The process by which new knowledge becomes embedded in the conceptual foundations and mental models of the scientific community.

concepts.label: Graph Neural Networks
concepts.description: Deep learning architectures that operate on graph-structured data to learn node/edge representations and make predictions.

concepts.label: Hypothesis Generation
concepts.description: The process of formulating testable scientific propositions or conjectures based on evidence and reasoning.

concepts.label: Dimensionality Reduction
concepts.description: Mathematical technique to project high-dimensional data into lower-dimensional spaces while preserving salient structure.

concepts.label: Hypothesis Validation
concepts.description: Experimental or computational testing of scientific hypotheses to determine their truth or utility.

concepts.label: Interactive Visualization
concepts.description: Visual interface enabling users to explore, query, and manipulate data representations in real-time.

concepts.label: Hallucination
concepts.description: Phenomenon where language models generate plausible but false or unfounded statements without factual grounding.

concepts.label: Human Expertise
concepts.description: Specialized knowledge, judgment, and interpretive capability developed through training and experience by domain professionals.

concepts.label: HypoChainer
concepts.description: Collaborative visualization framework integrating LLMs, knowledge graphs, and human expertise for hypothesis-driven scientific discovery.

concepts.label: Knowledge Base Question Answering
concepts.description: Task of answering natural language questions by querying structured knowledge bases containing entities and relations.

concepts.label: Few-shot Learning
concepts.description: Machine learning paradigm where models learn to perform tasks with minimal annotated examples, typically 110 samples.

concepts.label: SPARQL Queries
concepts.description: Structured query language for retrieving and manipulating data from RDF knowledge graphs.

concepts.label: Synthetic Data Generation
concepts.description: Automated creation of training examples through algorithmic sampling and transformation of existing data or knowledge.

concepts.label: Program Synthesis
concepts.description: Automated generation of executable programs (queries, code) to solve tasks specified by examples or constraints.

concepts.label: Self-training
concepts.description: Semi-supervised learning technique leveraging unlabeled data by iteratively training on model predictions with high confidence.

concepts.label: Distribution Shift
concepts.description: Mismatch between training and deployment data distributions, causing performance degradation in real-world scenarios.

concepts.label: Lightweight Models
concepts.description: Computationally efficient neural models with fewer parameters, optimized for inference speed and resource constraints.

concepts.label: Zero-shot Learning
concepts.description: Ability to perform tasks on unseen classes or domains without task-specific training examples.

concepts.label: Entity Linking
concepts.description: Process of mapping mentions in natural language text to corresponding entities in a knowledge base.

concepts.label: Natural Language Translation
concepts.description: Conversion between natural language questions and formal query representations using language models.

concepts.label: GrailQA
concepts.description: Benchmark dataset for evaluating KBQA systems with focus on handling diverse question types and entities.

concepts.label: automated driving
concepts.description: Research area focused on developing autonomous vehicle systems capable of perceiving, planning, and executing driving tasks without human intervention.

concepts.label: Knowledge embedding
concepts.description: Continuous vector representation of entities and relations in a knowledge graph, enabling efficient vector-based computation.

concepts.label: perception
concepts.description: Task of sensing and interpreting environmental information from sensors (camera, lidar, radar) to detect objects and understand the driving scene.

concepts.label: scene understanding
concepts.description: Process of analyzing detected objects and their spatial-temporal relationships to comprehend the overall driving context and road situation.

concepts.label: motion planning
concepts.description: Task of computing collision-free and safe trajectories for the vehicle based on perceived environment and driving objectives.

concepts.label: validation
concepts.description: Process of verifying and testing autonomous driving systems to ensure reliability, safety, and compliance with functional and regulatory requirements.

concepts.label: graph-structured data
concepts.description: Data represented as networks of interconnected nodes and edges capturing complex relationships and inter-dependencies between entities.

concepts.label: reliability
concepts.description: Property of a system to perform its intended function consistently and correctly over repeated use and varying conditions.

concepts.label: safety
concepts.description: Assurance that an automated system operates without causing harm to passengers, pedestrians, or property during normal and edge-case scenarios.

concepts.label: Knowledge graph reasoning
concepts.description: The process of inferring new facts and relations from existing knowledge graphs through logical inference or predictive models.

concepts.label: Symbolic logic
concepts.description: Formal logical systems using symbols and rules for deterministic, explainable reasoning over structured knowledge.

concepts.label: Embedding-based reasoning
concepts.description: Reasoning approach that uses continuous vector representations of entities and relations to predict plausible knowledge through neural computation.

concepts.label: Uncertainty handling
concepts.description: The capability to reason with incomplete, ambiguous, or probabilistic information without requiring deterministic ground truth.

concepts.label: Logic and embedding integration
concepts.description: A hybrid approach combining symbolic logical rules with continuous vector embeddings to leverage advantages of both paradigms.

concepts.label: Vector computation
concepts.description: Efficient mathematical operations on continuous vector representations enabling scalable neural inference.

concepts.label: scientific research
concepts.description: A systematic process applying methods of scientific inquiry to solve consequential problems, satisfy human wants, exploit opportunities, and cope with environmental threats.

concepts.label: science
concepts.description: Systematic discovery of root causes of phenomena to explain and predict them within contexts of economic and social adaptation.

concepts.label: socioeconomic driving forces
concepts.description: Social and economic interests, pressures, and motivations that shape the direction and intensity of scientific research production within nations.

concepts.label: national power
concepts.description: Political, military, and strategic superiority achieved through advances in science and technology.

concepts.label: wealth creation
concepts.description: Economic value generation and material prosperity resulting from technological innovation and scientific advancement.

concepts.label: R&D investment
concepts.description: Financial resources and capital allocated by nations to research and development activities.

concepts.label: research productivity
concepts.description: Output and effectiveness of scientific research measured in discoveries, publications, innovations, and solutions.

concepts.label: environmental threats
concepts.description: External challenges such as climate change, disease, or resource scarcity that motivate research responses.

concepts.label: organized social effort
concepts.description: Coordinated institutional and societal mobilization including scientists, governments, and industries toward research goals.

concepts.label: research policy
concepts.description: Government and institutional frameworks, regulations, and strategies governing the direction and funding of scientific research.

concepts.label: human wants
concepts.description: Societal needs and desires that drive research to develop solutions and improvements to living standards.

concepts.label: Educational recommendation system
concepts.description: A system that predicts and recommends learning resources to students based on their knowledge state and engagement patterns.

concepts.label: Semantic relatedness
concepts.description: The measure of conceptual similarity or meaningful connection between knowledge topics or learning domains.

concepts.label: TrueLearn algorithm
concepts.description: A Bayesian machine learning algorithm for predicting learner engagement and latent knowledge state in educational systems.

concepts.label: Semantic TrueLearn
concepts.description: An extension of the TrueLearn algorithm that incorporates semantic relatedness between knowledge components to improve prediction of learner engagement.

concepts.label: Learner model
concepts.description: A computational representation of a learner's knowledge state, capabilities, and learning characteristics used for personalization and prediction.

concepts.label: Latent knowledge
concepts.description: Implicit or hidden knowledge state of a learner that is not directly observable but inferred through engagement patterns and assessment.

concepts.label: Learner engagement
concepts.description: The degree of active involvement and interaction a learner exhibits with learning resources and educational content.

concepts.label: Wikipedia link graph
concepts.description: The network structure of Wikipedia articles connected by hyperlinks, representing semantic relationships between topics.

concepts.label: Knowledge component
concepts.description: A distinct, measurable unit of knowledge or skill within a domain that contributes to learning and competency.

concepts.label: Bayesian machine learning
concepts.description: A probabilistic machine learning approach that models uncertainty through Bayesian inference and belief updating.

concepts.label: Lifelong learning
concepts.description: A continuous learning paradigm where learners engage with educational content over extended periods, building knowledge incrementally.

concepts.label: Predictive performance
concepts.description: The accuracy and effectiveness of a model in predicting unobserved outcomes such as engagement or knowledge state.

edges.evidence: Constructing product KGs directly from unstructured product descriptions via automated framework.
Leveraging Large Language Models (LLMs), our method operates in three stages using dedicated agents.
Dedicated agents for ontology creation and expansion as first stage of the framework.
Ontology refinement as dedicated second stage with specialized agents.
Knowledge graph population as third stage executed by dedicated agents.
Ontology provides the formal specification of concepts and relationships used in KG construction.
First stage creates and expands the ontology from product descriptions.
Agent-based approach ensures semantic coherence during refinement stage.
KGs offer structured, interpretable format to support information retrieval tasks.
Structured KG format supports recommendation systems for e-commerce.
E-commerce platforms generate vast amounts of unstructured product data.
Framework automates KG population through three coordinated agent stages.
Framework achieves over 97% property coverage in KG population evaluation.
Agent-based approach ensures semantic coherence and high-quality output without predefined schemas.
IPPOG has been making concerted and systematic efforts to present and popularise particle physics across all audiences and age groups since 1997.
IPPOG operates as a strategic pillar in fostering long-term, sustainable support through outreach activities.
RDB is an online platform containing a collection of high quality engaging education and outreach materials in particle physics.
One of the main tools IPPOG has been offering to the scientific community is the Resource Database.
IPPOG bridges the gap between science education at school and modern scientific research through outreach activities.
RDB contains education and outreach materials in particle physics and related sciences.
IPPOG fosters long-term, sustainable support for fundamental research around the world through outreach.
IPPOG offers the Resource Database to the scientific community, teachers and educators.
Large language models provide a new tool to extract key concepts from vast literature beyond keyword searches, resulting in 24,939 concepts from 297,807 publications.
Extracted concepts were used to form a knowledge graph where link strength was determined by citation-reference relationships.
Link strength between concepts in the knowledge graph was determined by their relevance through citation-reference relationships.
The knowledge graph quantifies the integration of new ideas and technological advancements in astronomical research and how these drive scientific breakthroughs.
The knowledge graph demonstrates the impact of numerical simulations on astronomical research, showing its role in driving discovery.
The knowledge graph quantified the impact of machine learning on astronomical research, demonstrating its contribution to discovery.
Identifying factors that contribute to interdisciplinary research success includes understanding how technological advancements drive scientific breakthroughs.
The knowledge graph demonstrates two phases of development: a phase where the technology was integrated.
The knowledge graph demonstrates two phases of development: another phase where the technology was explored in scientific discovery.
The knowledge graph reveals a sequential development pattern where integration phase occurs before exploration phase.
Machine learning has made much inroad in astronomy; concepts were extracted from 297,807 astronomical publications.
There is currently a lack of new concept development at the intersection of AI and Astronomy, which may be the current bottleneck preventing machine learning from further transforming astronomy.
AI-astronomy intersection represents the convergence domain where machine learning methods meet astronomical research.
The proposed methodology introduces a system comprising multiple LLM agents that map tables and columns to Schema.org terms.
Semantic agents leverage large language models for semantic mapping and interpretation.
Mapping tables and columns to standardized terms enables construction of knowledge graphs for data integration.
The proposed methodology introduces a semantic layer above tables in relational databases.
Integrating disparate data sources enables businesses to overcome interoperability challenges.
Semantic mapping focuses on mapping tables and columns to Schema.org terms.
Semantic mapping leverages existing vocabularies like Schema.org for connecting structured data.
A semantic layer above database tables facilitates the creation of knowledge graphs.
Multiple LLM agents map tables and columns to Schema.org terms.
Knowledge graphs enable integration of disparate data sources, unlocking data potential across systems.
Paper introduces cognitive flow as an extension of flow theory in AI-augmented reasoning context.
Flow theory describes optimal cognitive state where task difficulty aligns with skill level.
Flow occurs when task difficulty aligns with individual's skill level.
Interventions that disrupt the state of cognitive flow can hinder rather than enhance decision-making.
Framework adapts interventions based on three key contextual factors: type, timing, and scale.
AI leverages multimodal behavioral cues to dynamically adjust cognitive support.
Gaze behavior is listed as one example of multimodal behavioral cues.
Timing is identified as a key contextual factor in the augmentation framework.
Scale is identified as a key contextual factor in the augmentation framework.
AI dynamically adjusts cognitive support to maintain or restore flow.
Approach ensures AI systems support deep engagement without disrupting cognitive immersion.
AI-augmented reasoning aims to enhance decision-making through cognitive support.
Framework is proposed as an approach to AI-augmented reasoning.
Flow theory describes state where individuals experience intrinsic motivation.
Medical LLMs necessitate that these models possess accurate medical knowledge for diagnostic assistance and treatment recommendations.
Medical contexts necessitate that these models deliver traceable decision-making processes.
Technologies such as knowledge graphs are used to integrate clinical knowledge into LLMs through KG-supported approaches.
RAG-assisted LLMs represent a key technology for embedding clinical knowledge into medical models.
Integration initiatives encompass traditional text and multimodal data integration for embedding clinical knowledge.
Specialized datasets are used as implementations for integrating clinical knowledge through training.
Reliable knowledge sources from the medical domain are gathered, including databases and datasets.
External knowledge sources such as KGs serve as collaborations for integrating clinical knowledge.
Medical LLMs are developed for applications such as diagnostic assistance and treatment recommendations.
Medical LLMs serve to provide treatment recommendations as a key clinical application.
Evaluation systems are applicable to assess medical LLM performance on relevant tasks.
Various initiatives aim to embed clinical knowledge into training-based, KG-supported, and RAG-assisted LLMs.
RAG techniques support traceable decision-making by retrieving and citing external knowledge sources.
Structured knowledge representations in KGs facilitate interpretable and auditable clinical reasoning.
The research evaluates several Natural Language Processing strategies to automate literature review generation.
RAG with LLM is one of the three primary approaches evaluated for automating literature review generation.
Transformer model (Simple T5) is utilized as one of three systems for auto-generating literature reviews.
spaCy frequency-based method is implemented as one of the three distinct techniques for auto-generating literature reviews.
RAG framework is implemented with GPT-3.5-turbo as the language model component.
ROUGE scores are used for evaluation; GPT-3.5-turbo achieved the highest ROUGE-1 score of 0.364.
ROUGE scores are used to evaluate the transformer model system; it came in second place.
ROUGE scores evaluate the frequency-based spaCy system, which ranked last among the three approaches.
PDF files serve as the primary input source for the automated literature review generation system.
The SciTLDR dataset is chosen for the research experiment to evaluate the three literature review generation systems.
A GUI is created for the best system based on the large language model (GPT-3.5-turbo).
Both models are compared for literature review generation; LLM outperforms transformer in ROUGE-1 score (0.364 vs second place).
Crowdsourced annotator bias often leads to superficial over-fitted correlations between questions and answers exploited by shortcut learning.
Current deep embedding models exploit shortcut learning rather than correctly performing knowledge-based visual question reasoning.
Controlled programs replace crowdsource annotation with systematic generation to disentangle knowledge from other biases.
Programs select triplets from the scene graph and external knowledge base to generate question-answer pairs.
External knowledge base provides triplets that programs can select for question generation and reasoning.
Programs select one or two triplets from the scene graph or knowledge base to construct reasoning steps.
Multiple triplets can be related to a question, enabling multi-step reasoning for answer derivation.
Multi-step reasoning is pushed by the dataset design to enforce knowledge-based visual question reasoning.
A desirable VQA model should correctly perceive the image context as a fundamental capability.
A desirable VQA model should understand the question as a core component of the task.
VQA models should incorporate learned knowledge to successfully answer visual questions.
Constraint that only one knowledge triplet relates to the image object enforces correct image perception rather than knowledge guessing.
Balanced answer distribution prevents models from exploiting biased answer frequency as a shortcut.
Deep embedding models must learn to integrate visual and knowledge representations for reasoning.
The proposed dataset with controlled programs is designed to evaluate and challenge deep representation embedding models.
We develop the DepthQA dataset, deconstructing questions into three depths based on a hierarchical graph.
DepthQA deconstructs questions into three depths: (i) recalling conceptual knowledge.
DepthQA deconstructs questions into three depths: (ii) applying procedural knowledge.
DepthQA deconstructs questions into three depths: (iii) analyzing strategic knowledge.
We propose a method that deconstructs complex real-world questions into a graph, representing each question as a node.
We quantify forward discrepancy, a discrepancy in LLM performance on simpler sub-problems versus complex questions.
Smaller models exhibit more discrepancies than larger models.
Distinct patterns of discrepancies are observed across model capacity and possibility of training data memorization.
Despite the advances in large language models (LLMs), how they use their knowledge for reasoning is not yet well understood.
Guiding models from simpler to complex questions through multi-turn interactions improves performance across model sizes.
This work enhances our understanding of LLM reasoning and suggests ways to improve their problem-solving abilities through structured intermediate steps.
Hierarchical depths: (i) recalling conceptual knowledge, (ii) applying procedural knowledge, (iii) analyzing strategic knowledge.
Hierarchical depths: (i) recalling conceptual knowledge, (ii) applying procedural knowledge, (iii) analyzing strategic knowledge.
LLMs are black-box models, which often fall short of capturing and accessing factual knowledge.
KGs are structured knowledge models that explicitly store rich factual knowledge.
KGs can enhance LLMs by providing external knowledge for inference and interpretability.
LLMs can leverage KGs for different KG tasks such as embedding, completion, construction, and generation.
KG-enhanced LLMs incorporate KGs during the pre-training and inference phases of LLMs.
KG-enhanced LLMs incorporate KGs during the pre-training and inference phases of LLMs, or for enhancing understanding of knowledge learned by LLMs.
LLM-augmented KGs leverage LLMs for different KG tasks such as embedding, completion, construction, graph-to-text generation, and question answering.
LLM-augmented KGs leverage LLMs for different KG tasks.
Synergized LLMs + KGs in which LLMs and KGs play equal roles and work in a mutually beneficial way.
Synergized LLMs + KGs in which LLMs and KGs play equal roles and work in a mutually beneficial way.
Synergized LLMs + KGs enhance both LLMs and KGs for bidirectional reasoning driven by both data and knowledge.
LLM-augmented KGs leverage LLMs for KG tasks such as embedding.
LLM-augmented KGs leverage LLMs for KG tasks such as completion.
LLM-augmented KGs leverage LLMs for KG tasks such as construction.
LLM-augmented KGs leverage LLMs for KG tasks such as graph-to-text generation.
LLM-augmented KGs leverage LLMs for KG tasks such as question answering.
The approach employs state-of-the-art Natural Language Processing tools for extracting entities from research publications.
NLP and Text Mining tools are used to extract relationships from research publications.
Machine Learning methods are employed for extracting entities from research publications.
Machine Learning is used as part of the extraction framework for identifying relationships in text.
State-of-the-art Text Mining tools are employed to tackle the challenge of knowledge extraction.
Entity and relationship extraction are components of the knowledge extraction process.
Entity and relationship extraction are components of the knowledge extraction process.
Extracted entities and relationships are then integrated into a large-scale knowledge graph through information integration.
Integration of extracted entities and relationships generates a knowledge graph structure.
Scientific knowledge graphs are knowledge graphs focused specifically on the scholarly domain.
Scientific knowledge graphs typically contain metadata describing research publications such as authors, venues, organizations, research topics, and citations.
The approach extracts entities and relationships from research publications and their abstracts.
The approach is applied to the Semantic Web domain as a chosen use case, generating 109,105 triples from 26,827 abstracts.
The architecture takes advantage of Natural Language Processing methods for extracting entities and relationships from research publications.
Corpus distillation seeks to address insufficient quantity and quality in open-source annotated scientific corpora, which is a bottleneck for effective LLM training in biomedical research.
Central to the approach is a collaborative multi-agent architecture where specialized agents work in concert to autonomously extract, synthesize, and self-evaluate high-quality textual data.
Each specialized agent is guided by the Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) hierarchy to ensure consistency with biomedical knowledge structures.
The agentic framework autonomously extracts textual data from scientific literature to generate and refine domain-specific question-answer pairs.
Agents self-evaluate and refine question-answer pairs, minimizing manual involvement while ensuring comprehensive coverage and consistency.
The framework generates domain-specific question-answer pairs that serve as training data for biomedical LLMs.
Generated question-answer pairs must ensure consistency with biomedical ontologies.
Language models trained on the distilled datasets achieve notable improvements in biomedical question-answering tasks.
Agents autonomously extract high-quality textual data from vast scientific literature.
Higher quality distilled training data correlates with improved performance on biomedical question-answering benchmarks.
Llama3-70B trained on the distilled dataset surpassed GPT-4 with MedPrompt and Med-PaLM-2 on biomedical tasks.
Multi-agent collaboration ensures high-quality data generation and refinement, with ablation studies validating the synergy of each agent.
Knowledge graphs are incomplete and relation prediction tackles this challenge by completing their information.
Methods tackle relation prediction by learning embeddings for entities and relations, then employing them to predict new relations.
Relation prediction methods employ learned embeddings for relations among entities.
MP acquires entities' context information through an attention-enhanced message-passing scheme.
Message passing captures entities' local semantics while focusing on different aspects of their neighborhood.
Empirical findings show how attention mechanisms can improve entities' context representation.
Most methods focus only on local neighbors of a relation to learn embeddings.
Methods may fail to capture KGs' context information by neglecting long-term dependencies.
MP captures semantic context by leveraging the paths and their relationships between entities.
Combining entities and semantic path contexts improves the general representation of entities.
Combining entities and semantic path contexts improves relation predictions.
Learning contextualized graph representations improves relation prediction performance.
The discovery of fullerenes in 1985 is analyzed as the scientific discovery that triggered a process which led to research in nanotubes.
Knowledge emergence effects on the structure of scientific communication; changes reflected in journals, terminology, and cognitive foundations.
Network analysis is applied to understand emergence institutionally, semantically, and cognitively.
The discovery of fullerenes in 1985 triggered a process which led to research in nanotubes.
Emergence understood semantically as changes in the codification of meaning in terms of words.
Emergence understood institutionally as changes in the journals.
Emergence understood cognitively as the new knowledge becomes the emergent foundation of further developments.
Discovery of fullerenes drives changes in scientific terminology and conceptual framing within communication systems.
Journals and organizational structures are fundamental components of scientific communication networks.
HypoChainer integrates human expertise, LLM-driven reasoning, and knowledge graphs to enhance hypothesis generation.
HypoChainer is a collaborative framework that integrates human expertise, LLM-driven reasoning, and knowledge graphs.
HypoChainer integrates human expertise, LLM-driven reasoning, and knowledge graphs to enhance hypothesis generation.
LLMs offer promise in filtering and hypothesis generation, yet suffer from hallucinations and lack grounding in structured knowledge.
LLMs suffer from hallucinations and lack grounding in structured knowledge, limiting their reliability.
Retrieval-augmented LLMs (RAGs) ground outputs in structured knowledge, addressing the hallucination problem.
LLM hallucinations and lack of grounding limit their reliability for hypothesis generation in scientific discovery.
Experts iteratively examine KG relationships around predictions and semantically linked entities, refining hypotheses with KG suggestions.
Refined hypotheses are filtered based on KG-supported evidence to identify high-priority candidates for experimentation.
GNNs have accelerated prediction generation, providing outputs that require manual selection for validation.
Experts use retrieval-augmented LLMs (RAGs) to navigate large-scale GNN predictions, assisted by interactive explanations.
Experts use dimensionality reduction to navigate large-scale GNN predictions during exploration and contextualization.
Interactive explanations assist experts in exploration, and visual analytics strengthen weak links in reasoning during validation.
HypoChainer enhances hypothesis generation and validation to support hypothesis-driven scientific discovery.
HypoChainer identifies high-priority candidates for experimentation through validation prioritization, supporting scalable discovery.
Knowledge graphs encode domain knowledge as structured semantic networks of entities and relationships.
FlexKBQA addresses the few-shot KBQA task due to insufficient high-quality annotated data in real-world scenarios.
LLMs function as program translators, converting SPARQL queries into natural language questions.
Automated algorithms sample diverse SPARQL programs from the knowledge base.
LLMs convert SPARQL queries into natural language questions to create synthetic training datasets.
Synthetic datasets facilitate training a specialized lightweight model for the knowledge base.
Execution-guided self-training reduces distribution shift between synthetic data and real user questions.
Self-training iteratively leverages unlabeled user questions to improve lightweight model performance.
LLMs' inherent reasoning capability is harnessed to enhance the overall KBQA framework.
FlexKBQA achieves results in both few-shot and more challenging zero-shot scenarios.
Specialized lightweight models trained on synthetic data address KBQA task with efficiency.
KBQA systems must resolve entities within knowledge bases containing vast numbers of entities.
SPARQL queries are sampled first, then converted into natural language questions by LLMs.
KGs have recently gained significant attention from both industry and academia for applications that benefit by exploiting structured, dynamic, and relational data in automated driving tasks.
Deep learning methods have made remarkable breakthroughs in machine learning in general and in automated driving in particular.
Recent progress in graph neural networks allows applying machine learning to graph-structured data with complex relationships and inter-dependencies.
Recent progress in knowledge graph embeddings allows applying machine learning to graph-structured data.
Ontologies are listed as a main task of AD where knowledge graphs can be applied, indicating KGs build upon or include ontological structures.
KG-based approaches are applied to the main task of perception in automated driving to incorporate structured knowledge about objects and relationships.
KGs are applied to scene understanding, one of the main tasks of AD, enabling structured representation of spatial-temporal relationships and context.
Motion planning is identified as a main task where KG-based approaches can be applied to improve trajectory computation using structured relational data.
Validation is listed as a main task of AD where KGs can contribute to systematic testing and verification of autonomous driving systems.
Scene understanding interprets the driving context which is necessary input for motion planning to compute safe and appropriate trajectories.
Perception detects objects from sensor data, which feeds into scene understanding to interpret spatial-temporal relationships and driving context.
Knowledge graphs are structured representations of entities and relationships, making them instances of graph-structured data.
Ensuring reliability and safety of automated systems is identified as an unsolved problem that KGs aim to address through effective knowledge incorporation.
Ensuring safety of automated systems is an unsolved problem and key challenge that motivates the application of KGs to AD tasks.
KGs effectively incorporate all available information and knowledge in the driving task, contributing to system reliability and trustworthiness.
KGs enable structured representation and reasoning about driving scenarios and dependencies, supporting safety assurance in automated driving systems.
KG reasoning is the process of inferring new facts from existing knowledge graphs.
Conventional KG reasoning based on symbolic logic results in explainable reasoning results.
Logic-based reasoning is a conventional approach to KG reasoning.
Modern embedding-based reasoning can deal with uncertainty and predict plausible knowledge.
Embedding-based methods can predict plausible knowledge from KGs.
Vector representations of embeddings enable efficient vector computation for high efficiency.
Embedding-based reasoning utilizes continuous vector representations of entities and relations.
Integrating logic-based and embedding-based methods is a promising direction for KG reasoning.
Logic and embedding integration combines symbolic logic with embeddings.
Logic and embedding integration combines embedding-based reasoning with logic.
Hybrid approaches aim to have advantages of both logic-based explainability and embedding efficiency.
Integrated methods combine logic's determinism with embeddings' ability to handle uncertainty.
Scientific research is produced for social and economic interests of nations (power, wealth creation, technological superiority, etc.), rather than philosophical inquiries.
Scientific research is driven by concerns and interests of nations to achieve advances that reflect desires for power and strategic advantage.
Nations produce scientific research to explain sources of social power and wealth creation.
Scientific research is driven by national interests in achieving technological superiority.
Research growth is due to general social efforts of nations to cope with environmental threats, such as war.
Scientific research is a systematic process applying methods to satisfy human wants and take advantage of important opportunities.
Scientific research is driven by an organized social effort that inevitably reflects concerns and interests of nations.
Relationships between R&D investment and productivity are discussed as key drivers of scientific output.
Science discovers root causes of phenomena; scientific research is the systematic process applying scientific methods to solve problems.
Research policy implications are discussed as frameworks governing scientific research direction and outcomes.
National interests in power and technological superiority drive nations to produce research that advances their strategic position.
Economic interests of nations motivate research as a source of wealth creation through technological advancement.
Semantic TrueLearn builds upon TrueLearn with a simple extension that adds semantic awareness to the model.
Semantic TrueLearn is introduced as a state-aware educational recommendation system.
Semantic TrueLearn exploits semantic relatedness between knowledge components using the Wikipedia link graph.
The system aims to better predict learner engagement by propagating latent information across semantically related topics.
Semantic relatedness is used to better predict learner engagement and latent knowledge in a lifelong learning scenario.
The Wikipedia link graph is leveraged as the semantic knowledge graph source for encoding topic relationships.
Semantic TrueLearn exploits semantic relatedness between knowledge components in learning resources.
The learner model aims to predict learner engagement and latent knowledge state.
Semantic TrueLearn leverages Bayesian machine learning to improve the predictive performance of educational engagement.
Experiments demonstrate that Semantic TrueLearn achieves statistically significant improvements in terms of predictive performance.
The system is designed for a lifelong learning scenario where continuous prediction of learner engagement is needed.
Semantic knowledge graphs enable the development of a humanly intuitive knowledge representation in the learner model.
